news.title: Trump posts racist meme of the Obamas - then deletes it
news.text:
In the first week of Black History Month, President Trump posted a racist depiction of former President Barack Obama and first lady Michelle Obama on social media â€” a video clip showing the Obamas' faces on apes. The post was later deleted, and the White House blamed a staffer for "erroneously" posting it.

It was one of dozens of posts Trump shared in the middle of the night on his platform Truth Social and came at the end of a minute-long video promoting conspiracy theories about the 2020 election.

White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt defended the clip before it was deleted, saying "please stop the fake outrage." 

Leavitt said it was from an "internet meme" that depicted Trump as king of the jungle while Democrats were shown as characters from The Lion King. Trump's clip did not include any of the longer video Leavitt referred to, which also includes other Democrats, such as Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and New York Mayor Zohran Mamdani, depicted as animals.

The racist trope depicting Black people as apes or animals has historically been used to dehumanize Black people and to justify slavery.

Criticism of Trump and his post came swiftly, including from some otherwise allied with Trump.

South Carolina Sen. Tim Scott, a Republican, said he was "praying it was fake."

"It's the most racist thing I've seen out of this White House. The President should remove it," said Scott, who is Black.

Trump has a history of making racist remarks toward Black people and other people of color.

For years he pushed the false narrative that Obama was not born in the U.S., and he has previously used derogatory language to describe African countries.

He also falsely claimed former Vice President Kamala Harris "turned Black" during the presidential campaign. Harris identifies as Black and Indian American.
news.summary: Trump's racist post came at the end of a minute-long video promoting conspiracy theories about the 2020 election.Â
news.author: Deepa Shivaram

news.title: Bully Trump cut me out â€” because he couldn't scare me
news.text:
Thereâ€™s been a lot of support this week for CNNâ€™s Kaitlan Collins, who got berated by the Giant Orange Snowflake Epstein Bestie for simply Doing A Journalism While Female in the Oval Office.

 But itâ€™s also a classic example of who Trump has always been, and therefore should be used as an example of how to fight back against him.

The vainglorious, short-fingered vulgarian bloviated loudly, steamrolled Collinsâ€™ questions, and even busted out some tired â€œYou should smile moreâ€ misogyny that no woman in history has ever enjoyed hearing, especially from someone whoâ€™s never given any of us anything to smile about.

 Bullies are the weakest people. Thereâ€™s nothing strong about needing to put another person down, to feel bigger and stronger. They learn soon that no one will respect them, so the next best thing is to instill fear.

At the same time, all bullying is rooted in jealousy. In Trumpâ€™s case, it also comes with a whopping dose of self-victimization and the need to assert power over anyone who might expose him as the spineless coward he is.

 As kids, weâ€™re taught to stand up to bullies, even if theyâ€™re bigger. â€œDonâ€™t let them push you around like that!â€ my father barked at me when I was bullied in sixth grade. Imagine if Trump had been a truck driver in New Jersey in the 1970s and '80s â€” thatâ€™s my dad. He bullied me for getting bullied, so I learned how to stand up and push back. That included pushing back at him. Instead of letting my abuser continue to abuse me, I cut him out of my life.

 Thatâ€™s not as easy to do with Trump, but itâ€™s a problem that never should have existed. When he descended that gold escalator to launch his first bid for president in 2015, I knew exactly what he was: a smarmy, slimy, chauvinistic playboy who thought he was better looking and more powerful than he actually was. 

 Groomed first by Roy Cohn, then by Vladimir Putin, Donny Daddy Issues got all the attention and ego-boosting he thirsted for. The false bravado grew as he created his own legend. He famously pushed back against any woman who interviewed him â€” like Barbara Walters and Lesley Stahl.

 When he hit the campaign trail, his attacks on the media surged. Even the most professional of journalists were taken aback by his attacks â€” but few were able to prevail over the tactics he learned from Daddy Vladdy: deny, deflect, and distract.

 Trump was astute enough to understand how to play to his few strengths. E. Jean Carroll can attest to how he used his physicality to intimidate women, and weâ€™ve all seen him steamroll anyone who asks questions he doesnâ€™t like. 

Guess who else asked him questions he didnâ€™t like?

 Me, thatâ€™s who. 

 Iâ€™m 5ft tall and weigh maybe a buck-five, so I love knowing that huge homunculus of an adjudicated rapist is scared of me. 

Such a fearless leader, huh? Yell louder, Tiny. I canâ€™t hear you because youâ€™ve never unblocked me.

MAGA loves the â€œloudest person is always rightâ€ approach, because then they donâ€™t have to hear anything that makes them feel bad. Theyâ€™ve all taken on Trumpâ€™s persona in their pursuit of â€œowning the Libs,â€ a goal apparently more important than making sure they can feed their families or afford health care. And that whole Epstein files thing? Just a â€œDemocrat hoaxâ€ pushed by the â€œfake news media.â€

 Iâ€™ve already written about Trumpâ€™s favorite way to scapegoat the media and any others who dare challenge him. But that certainly wasnâ€™t the first time I tried to get their attention. 

 Trumpâ€™s abusiveness left the mainstream media (MSM for short) incapable of covering Joe Biden accurately. While he and VP Kamala Harris were undoing the damage of the first illegitimate Trump regime, the MSM was all, â€œWill Trump run again?â€

 When Biden pulled us out of Trumpâ€™s pandemic depression and lifted all other global economies with us, the MSM breathlessly covered Trumpâ€™s FOUR DIFFERENT ARRESTS, simply watching as MAGA turned his mugshot into a badge of honor instead of yet another Hall of Shame moment.

 â€œThe MSM has PTSD from TFG,â€ I wrote in October 2023. Remember when Biden called Trump â€œThe Former Guyâ€? Dark Brandon shouldâ€™ve been the mediaâ€™s darling, not the convicted felon rapist who fomented an insurrection and stole classified documents from the White House. Itâ€™s still true. Ironically, I submitted that as an op-ed to the Washington Post, which has now fully capitulated to Putinâ€™s puppet. Its new masthead should read â€œTrumpism Over Journalism,â€ as it helps our democracy die, drowned in Dark Money.

 But if I can stand up to the bully, so can Kaitlan Collins and anyone else he targets. Trump will continue to abuse anyone who asks him about Epstein, but that canâ€™t mean no one asks him about Epstein. 

 My advice comes from my GenX experiences and every '80s movie where the bullies finally lose, after a montage where the nerds build a clubhouse or something, all set to â€œNew Songâ€ by Howard Jones.

Just ask Trump why heâ€™s never released the full and unredacted Epstein files, to exonerate himself. When Trump goes after that person â€” and he will â€” the next person should ask the same question. And the next. Use your voices together. Be louder than him. Say itâ€™s your job to get the truth to the people. He wonâ€™t know what to do with a united front like that, and youâ€™ll be exposing his weakness live on camera.

Give it a try. Itâ€™s only our democracy at stake. Use the truth as a shield instead of letting him hurt us with his lies.

Tara Dublin is a political writer/commentator based in Portland, OR, who has been blocked by Donald Trump on Twitter since August 2015 and can occasionally be heard as a fill-in host on SiriusXM Progress. She is also the author of The Sound of Settling, a rock â€˜nâ€™ roll love story available at taradublinrocks.com
news.author: Tara Dublin

news.title: Kamala HQ account changes X username after backlash over â€˜67â€™
news.text:
â€œItâ€™s where you can go online to get basically the latest of whatâ€™s going on, and also to meet and revisit with some of our great, courageous leaders,â€ Harris says in the video. â€œSo stay engaged, and Iâ€™ll see you out there.â€

The rebrand was created in partnership with the progressive nonprofit organization People For the American Way and alumni of the 2024 Harris campaign. Harris will serve in an honorary Headquarters role as chairwoman emerita.

The account relaunched on X as @Headquarters_67 on Thursday, but was later changed to @Headquarters68_.

â€œUsing the 67 meme to appeal to young people is just so deeply insulting to our intelligence. We want good jobs, green spaces, affordable homes, community, and a habitable planet,â€ Climate Defiance, a climate movement organization, wrote on X. â€œSpeaking to us through a washed up TikTok trend is infantilizing. Is it not?â€

â€œZohran Mamdani proved that Gen-Z wants to be talked to like actual adults and not just won over with s***** memes, the DNCâ€™s response to that is an account with 67 in the @,â€ another user wrote on X. 

The Washington Examiner contacted Luminary Strategies and People For the American Way for comment about the username change.

What is â€™67â€™?

Following the initial rebrand, some social media users were quick to criticize the accountâ€™s use of â€œ67â€ in the username. 

The term â€œ67,â€ pronounced â€œsix seven,â€ emerged as a popular slang with Generation Alpha and Generation Z on social media, and became Dictionary.comâ€™s word of the year in 2025.

â€œSix seven (or 67 or 6 7, etc.) is a nonsensical expression used especially by teens and tweens that is connected to a rap song and also to a 6â€™7â€ tall basketball player,â€ according to Merriam-Webster.

Some users online have argued that the term means â€œso-so,â€ especially when paired with a physical up-and-down hand motion. Other times, however, the term is used without any context as a random expression by young people.

The term originated in rapper Skrillaâ€™s song â€œDoot Doot (6 7)â€ and has been frequently used in viral basketball videos.

The song was used in a meme featuring video edits of NBA player LaMelo Ball, according to Merriam-Webster.

Urban Dictionary has a similar definition, but also says the term is used â€œrandomlyâ€ and does not have â€œany meaning.â€

â€œ(Six Seven) is a meme originating from the lyrics in a song called -Doot Doot-, later popularized by one kid on the internet who, from then on, was called the â€˜6-7 Kidâ€™ after a viral video showed him saying the term at a basketball game,â€ according to Urban Dictionary.
news.summary: Kamala HQ changed its X username again after the account was rebranded as the progressive content media hub Headquarters.  The X and TikTok accounts relaunched on Thursday under the new brand name Headquarters, with a video featuring former Vice President Kamala Harris sharing with users what to expect. This is the first time the account has […]
news.author: Sydney Topf

news.title: Fake outrage over internet meme: White House responds to Donald Trump's racist Obama video, deleted now
news.text: White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said the outrage over President Donald Trump's 'racist' video of showing the Obamas as apes is fake as it is from an internet meme video. Leavitt said the meme video depicted President Trump as the King of the Jungle and Democrats as characters from 'The Lion King'. â€œPlease stop the fake outrage and report on something today that actually matters to the American public,â€ Leavitt said in a statement to Newsweek.The AI-generated video was posted on X in October 2025 and showed many Democrats as animals bowing down to Trump. In the full video, Joe Biden appears as a baboon; Kamala Harris as a tortoise; Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer as a zebra; House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries as a meerkat; Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez as a donkey; New York City mayor Zohran Mamdani as a hyena; and Hillary Clinton as a warthog. Content creator Xerias took credit for the main video as it drew backlash after Trump shared it. "Disgusting behavior by the President," California Democratic Governor Gavin Newsom said in a post on X, reacting to the video. "Every single Republican must denounce this. Now."â€œPraying it was fake because itâ€™s the most racist thing Iâ€™ve seen out of this White House,â€ Republican senator Tim Scott wrote on X on Friday morning. â€œThe President should remove it.â€Video deleted, staff posted erroneouslyAfter Karoline Leavitt's justification of the meme video, some insiders claimed that a staff had erroneously made the post. A statement from a White House official â€” sent from an unsigned press email address â€” confirmed the video was removed and claimed an unidentified staffer had posted it to the presidentâ€™s social media account.Politico writer Sophia Cai said she was told that President Trump did not see the video and a staff was blamed. Only a handful of staffers have access to his Truth Social account, Cai observed. "Nope, not allowing the President to blame a racist post on his own account on White House staffers. This is the second story this morning from his PR team. The first didnâ€™t fly so now theyâ€™re putting it on his â€œteam"," NYT author Shannon Watts commented on the cover-up.
news.author: Toi World Desk

news.title: Trump Posts Video That Depicts Obamas as Apes
news.text:
Late Thursday night, President Donald Trump shared a video on Truth Social that depicts former President Barack Obama and former first lady Michelle Obama as apes. 

The post, which was online all of Friday morning, appears to have been removed from the presidentâ€™s page. 

Toward the end of an unrelated video alleging interference in the 2020 presidential election, a clip that is around 2 seconds long features the first Black president and his wife on the bodies of apes as â€œThe Lion Sleeps Tonightâ€ plays in the background. That clip comes from a longer video that a meme account posted in October. 

Mother Jones asked the White House a list of questions, including how Trump found the video, if he was aware that the 2020 election video contained that imagery when he posted it, and if the video depicting the Obamas was playing on the presidentâ€™s device. The press office did not respond to specific questions but instead sent over a statement from White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt. 

â€œThis is from an internet meme video depicting President Trump as the King of the Jungle and Democrats as characters from The Lion King,â€ Leavitt said. â€œPlease stop the fake outrage and report on something today that actually matters to the American public.â€

The video clip posted by the president just before midnight on the East Coast drew immense backlash, including from some Republicans. 

Sen. Tim Scott, a Republican from South Carolina, wrote on X: â€œPraying it was fake because itâ€™s the most racist thing Iâ€™ve seen out of this White House. The President should remove it.â€

The Democrats X page also condemned the video, writing, â€œThis is who Trump is: Sick, racist, and completely deranged.â€ 

The original video of the Obamas was seemingly created by the same account that made the AI-generated video of President Trump flying a fighter jet and dropping feces on â€œNo Kingsâ€ protesters. The userâ€™s bio reads â€œGod First | Trump â€˜Fighter Jet Poopâ€™ Guy.â€ In the full version of the video that Trump posted on Thursday, prominent Democrats are depicted as various animals, and President Trumpâ€™s head is on a lion with the caption â€œKing of the Jungle.â€ The Obamas are not the only Democrats included in this video. Former presidential candidate Hillary Clinton, Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, New York City Mayor Zohran Mamdani, former President Joe Biden, and former Vice President Kamala Harris all appear, among others. 

The presidentâ€™s post is the latest in a decades-long history of sharing or amplifying racist claims, from taking out a full-page ad in 1989 calling for the death penalty for the young Black and brown Central Park Five to boosting the Obama birtherism conspiracy theory for years. He has also not restricted this behavior to social media; during both of his terms, he has enacted policies that uniquely target Black people, such as a comprehensive attack on diversity, equity, and inclusion efforts in the federal government and private sector that began with an executive order on his first day in office.

Itâ€™s unclear how the video came across the presidentâ€™s screen, but the original creator is celebrating. Under his initial post of the video, he shared a screenshot of Thursdayâ€™s Truth Social post.

Minutes before and minutes after sharing the video, which included the racist imagery of the former first family, Trump had posted two videos about how the Republican Party is the best political home for Black people.
news.summary: Late Thursday night, President Donald Trump shared a video on Truth Social that depicts former President Barack Obama and former first lady Michelle Obama as apes.Â  The post, which was online all of Friday morning, appears to have been removed from the presidentâ€™s page.  Toward the end of an unrelated video alleging interference in the […]
news.author: Ari Berman,Katie Herchenroeder

news.title: Former Washington Post Staffers Slam Billionaire Bezos for Gutting Paper
news.text:
The Washington Post has laid off more than 300 journalists, dismantling its sports, local news and international coverage. â€œEverybody is grieving, and itâ€™s a loss for our readers,â€ says Nilo Tabrizy, one of the paperâ€™s recently laid-off staff, who describes a â€œroboticâ€ meeting announcing the cuts. â€œThey didnâ€™t have the dignity to look us in the eye.â€ The shocking staff culling has been widely attributed to the paperâ€™s leadership under Amazon founder Jeff Bezos, who bought the nearly 150-year-old institution in 2013. Karen Attiah, the former global opinion editor at the Post, was hired soon after Bezosâ€™s arrival. She recounts how the arrival of a billionaire backer initially revitalized the paper with resources and creative freedom, before souring over the next decade. â€œWe thought [he] shared the same values that we had,â€ says Attiah, who was fired from the Post last fall over comments she made about the death of conservative activist Charlie Kirk. â€œJournalism deserves better than a billionaire owner who decides that partying in Europe is more important than peopleâ€™s lives.â€

This is a rush transcript. Copy may not be in its final form.

AMY GOODMAN: Weâ€™re going to stay on the media right now. In whatâ€™s been described a â€œbloodbath,â€ The Washington Post has laid off more than 300 journalists, about 30% of all its employees, dismantling its sports, local news and international coverage, including all of the newspaperâ€™s Middle East correspondents and editors. The Postâ€™s Ukraine reporter Lizzie Johnson wrote on X, quote, â€œI was just laid off by The Washington Post in the middle of a war zone,â€ she wrote from Ukraine.

On Thursday, fired workers rallied outside The Washington Post office. This is the reporter Ben Brasch, who was fired Tuesday.

BEN BRASCH: These layoffs are shameful!

FIRED WORKERS: Shame!

BEN BRASCH: The fourth-richest person in the world, Jeff Bezos, owns The Washington Post. He can run it at a loss for the rest of time, and yet he refuses! And instead, heâ€™s spending tens of millions of dollars buying a documentary for Melania Trump to curry favor with the president of the United States. When people show you who they are, believe them. Billionaires only get rich by stealing from us.

AMY GOODMAN: Jeff Bezos bought The Washington Post in 2013. [In 2024], the paper lost over 250,000 digital subscribers after the paper announced it would not make an endorsement in the presidential race between Kamala Harris and Donald Trump. Bezosâ€™s Amazon later donated a million dollars to Trumpâ€™s inaugural fund.

Weâ€™re joined right now by two guests. Karen Attiah, former global opinion editor for The Washington Post, was fired last year over social media posts made after the killing of far-right activist Charlie Kirk. Nilo Tabrizy is an investigative reporter who closely covers Iran. She was just laid off from The Washington Post yesterday.

Nilo, letâ€™s start with you, whatâ€™s being termed a â€œbloodbath,â€ 300 employees of The Washington Post, a third of The Washington Post. You write about Iran. Talk about what happened in Iran. Talk about what happened with the Middle East coverage, overall, and whatâ€™s happened with all of your colleagues.

NILO TABRIZY: Yeah. Thank you. Iâ€™m glad to be here to discuss what happened at the Post.

So, our entire Middle East staff was laid off. Most of the international desk was dismantled, as well. And this is something that we heard was coming down in the newsroom a few weeks ago. And we also heard that when this plan was presented to Peter Finn, who is the head of the international desk and mentor to many at the Post, he said to them he would rather be laid off than deal with this horrible gutting and reconstruction, as it was, you know, phrased.

So, itâ€™s been incredibly depressing. Everybody is grieving. And itâ€™s a loss for our readers. Itâ€™s a loss for everyone. And the way the company is framing, you know, that we want to focus more on national security, well, international reporters and national security, I mean, these two desks collaborate so much with each other. And so, itâ€™s a deeply grim moment.

And, you know, as a member of the Post Guild, in the union at The Washington Post, weâ€™re lucky to have the guild fight for us, but international staff, theyâ€™re not members of the guild. And even worse, there are so many local workers that we work with at the Post. We have local drivers, translators, reporters that collaborate with our bureau chiefs and with our correspondents. Those people are not protected in the same way that I am. And so, itâ€™s incredibly awful. Thereâ€™s no words to describe the dismantling thatâ€™s happening at the Post.

JUAN GONZÃLEZ: And, Nilo, I wanted to ask you, especially this whole issue of the international reporting, with so few U.S. media companies still having even a skeleton staff of reporters reporting on affairs outside the United States: What does that turn The Washington Post into? And also, what does that say about the ability of the media in the U.S. to let people know in this country whatâ€™s going on in the rest of the world?

NILO TABRIZY: Right. I mean, itâ€™s a complete disservice. I mean, we do this job because we want to be in service to the public. This is the main intention for so many of us. And taking the ability away to do this type of reporting to communicate whatâ€™s important, I mean, itâ€™s a disservice to our readership and to anyone who wants to engage in these issues. I mean, my last story that I did for the Post, which published on Monday, the day before I got laid off, was about the buildup that weâ€™re seeing of vessels, of U.S. military equipment in the Persian Gulf, and potentially there might be some type of strike. And now the Post is not well placed to cover that. And itâ€™s incredibly heartbreaking.

JUAN GONZÃLEZ: Yeah, Iâ€™d like to bring Karen Attiah into the conversation, as well. Karen, your response to these layoffs? And Jeff Bezos was â€” while they were happening, was actually in Paris at a Haute Couture Week?

KAREN ATTIAH: Yeah, I mean, I joined the Post, and specifically the opinion section, right after Bezos bought the paper, so in about 2014. And I was, you know, there when we were kind of riding high, basically. We had not only Bezos cash â€” right? â€” but we had the permission, in a lot of ways, to be able to be creative, in order to be able to be swashbuckling, provocative. And for most of my time, a good chunk of my time in the opinion section, I was the global opinions editor, and we had a direct mandate, basically, from Bezos, saying that he wanted The Washington Post to be a global newspaper, that he wanted us to be the English-speaking newspaper that the rest of the world turned to. So, thatâ€™s why, you know, I got to work recruiting writers and building up that section of global writers, including Jamal Khashoggi, who was very brutally murdered in 2018. Jeff Bezos, we thought, shared the same values that we had, particularly when it came to international coverage and for standing up for journalists who werenâ€™t able to speak freely in their areas of the world.

And now to see him butchering the Post, or at least, at the very least, partying in Paris and in Europe while so many of my colleagues are being unceremoniously kicked out of their job, at a time when America desperately needs to know whatâ€™s going on in its own neighborhood and in the world, itâ€™s just â€” itâ€™s unconscionable, frankly.

AMY GOODMAN: And, Karen Attiah, you were the former global opinion editor for The Washington Post. You platformed many courageous voices, including Jamal Khashoggi, who would be murdered in the embassy in Turkey. And all the intelligence reports from the agencies of the United States government pointed the finger at a dear ally of President Trump, Prince Mohammed bin Salman. Your thoughts on your ousting? Yeah, it was the time of the assassination of Charlie Kirk, but what you represented at the Post?

KAREN ATTIAH: You know, so much about this is â€” breaks my heart still to this day. What breaks my heart is, yes, having the ability to give writers a home in times where they couldnâ€™t, and now when they ask, â€œWell, where can we be heard? Where can our voices go?â€ and I canâ€™t, in good conscience, say that they have a safe place in The Washington Post anymore.

You know, I think, for me, you know, I was illegally, I will say, fired for posting very â€” you know, posting the facts about gun violence in this country, about race in this country, and basically, you know, fired for doing my job. But the signs were all there, the censoring of the opinion page. When Bezos said that opinions that were outside of his scope of free markets and personal liberties, that was a red flashing sign that censorship and purging was going to come for The Washington Post. I tried to hold on for as long as I could and do the work that I was, you know, paid to do for as long as I could, until I couldnâ€™t. I mean, Iâ€™m still continuing to fight that termination, as well. So, I think, if anything, showing that we need to stand up to this purging is even more important. So, Iâ€™m definitely fighting back, with the assistance â€” and not just the assistance, but the guild has my back, so Iâ€™m grateful for that.

But this is a bigger moment. Thereâ€™s a reason why this is an international news story. I think The Washington Post stands for a lot more than just a media company. It stands for a lot more than even just journalism, I would say. For a lot of people around the world, theyâ€™re looking at The Washington Post as a proxy and a bellwether for whatâ€™s happening to America and democracy, right?

And when we are not able to even be able to freely cover our own neighborhoods, be able to freely cover the world, be able to, you know, under â€” D.C. being under military occupation, basically, with the National Guard, we canâ€™t even retain a diverse set of journalists in a city that is very much immigrants, people of color. There are probably, at this point, less than maybe 30 Black journalists left. I was the last Black columnist left at The Washington Post, full-time staff opinions columnist left at The Washington Post. So, the brazenness with which the destruction of the line of defense of journalism against oppression is just â€” itâ€™s as shameless on their end as it is cruel. And D.C. deserves better. This entire region deserves better. Journalism deserves better than a billionaire owner who decides that, you know, partying in Europe is more important than peopleâ€™s lives. The Washington Post deserves a better owner than this.

JUAN GONZÃLEZ: I wanted to ask Nilo Tabrizy about this, this enormous change in direction that Bezos has gone in with The Washington Post versus how he started, then his muzzling of the editorial page and then his fawning after Trump with the financing of the Melania film. What is your sense of the enormity of this change? Itâ€™s almost like a 180-degree turn on his part from where he started.

NILO TABRIZY: Absolutely. I mean, I canâ€™t say it better myself. Itâ€™s a complete departure from the mission of the Post and â€œDemocracy dies in darkness.â€ Well, now itâ€™s completely dark. And what do we have left?

AMY GOODMAN: Thatâ€™s the motto of The Washington Post, adopted in 2017.

NILO TABRIZY: Yes, thatâ€™s the motto of The Washington Post, exactly. And itâ€™s really â€” yeah, itâ€™s indescribable. And I really feel for my Post colleagues who now have to show up and work in a carcass of what this incredible institution was. The Post was such a special culture. It was different from any other newsroom Iâ€™ve worked in, where itâ€™s deeply collaborative. Desks were not competing for each other. Everyone was there for the same mission, which was to put out the best report. And theyâ€™ve completely dismantled that. And again, itâ€™s a deep disservice to any of our readers, to our public.

And it shows the fragility of these institutions and how important it is to protect them, because with one fell swoop, in a horrific layoff, you know, 30-minute robotic meeting, in which our publisher was not even present â€” we saw that our publisher, Will Lewis, was at some Super Bowl-related event â€” they didnâ€™t have the dignity to look us in the eye. You know, people got these mass emails: â€œYour job is eliminated.â€

AMY GOODMAN: And you were told not to come to work yesterday.

NILO TABRIZY: We were all told not to come to work. We had an 8:30 a.m. Zoom, which, in itself, is unconscionable. And then, after that, employees who even had, you know, 27-plus years of service were told they lost their job in a one-line email, where our publisher, again, was not present. This, again, really shows the lack of leadership at the Post.

AMY GOODMAN: Well, weâ€™re going to continue to cover this story and continue to cover the corporate media and remind people Democracy Now! is independent. Nilo Tabrizy, just laid off from The Washington Post, will stay with us as we talk about Iran next. And Karen Attiah, we thank you so much for joining us, former global opinion editor for The Washington Post.

This is Democracy Now! When we come back, the talks in Oman around Iran, between the United States and Iran, and then weâ€™ll talk about Gaza. Stay with us.
news.summary: â€œJournalism deserves better,â€ says Karen Attiah, who was fired last fall over comments about the death of Charlie Kirk.
news.author: Amy Goodman,Juan GonzÃ¡lez

news.title: NFL: Bad Bunny focuses on unity and culture ahead of historic Super Bowl show
news.text:
Puerto Rican artist won Grammy for Album of the YearAccepting Grammy award Sunday, he said â€˜Ice Out!â€™Trump blasts selection of singer as â€˜absolutely ridiculousâ€™

SAN FRANCISCO â€” Bad Bunny was thinking about his family, friends, and culture as he prepared for his historic Super Bowl LX halftime show on Sunday, where the Seattle Seahawks will face the New England Patriots in the NFL championship game.

The 31-year-old Puerto Rican star, whose album â€œDebÃ­ Tirar MÃ¡s Fotosâ€ won Album of the Year at last weekâ€™s Grammys, wants to bring a sense of belonging to people around the globe with his performance. Last yearâ€™s Super Bowl halftime show by Kendrick Lamar set a record, drawing more than 130 million viewers.

â€œMy biggest feeling is being grateful,â€ the artist, wearing an unusual beanie hat with bunny ears, told reporters on Thursday.

â€œI feel more excited about the people than even me, about my family, about my friends, people that I know that always believed in me and theyâ€™re happy because of this moment and the culture.â€

He emphasized unity and celebration as his main goals for the 13-minute performance and was candid about how his deeply personal album exceeded his expectations.

Bad Bunnyâ€™s selection as halftime headliner has drawn criticism from some traditionalists, including President Donald Trump, who called it â€œabsolutely ridiculous.â€

The artist has been outspoken in his criticism of Trumpâ€™s deportation policies and openly supported Kamala Harris in the 2024 presidential race.

Upon accepting one of his three Grammy awards last week, he declared â€œICE outâ€ from the stage, referencing U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

READ: Bad Bunny says â€˜ICE outâ€™ during Grammy awards acceptance speech

He notably skipped touring the continental U.S., citing fears that immigration agents would arrest his fans.

After announcing his residency in Puerto Rico, he recalled thinking: â€œOh, wow. The world really wants me. So I should go also to give some love, show love to the world, to Latin America.â€

â€œAnd then the opportunity to bring that feeling that I put on that album to one of the biggest stages in the world is something that I never thought,â€ he said.

When asked about potential guest appearances, Bad Bunny, or â€œEl Conejo Maloâ€, deflected with characteristic warmth:

â€œI think I have a lot of guests. Itâ€™s gonna be my family, my friends, or all the Latino community around the world.â€

He even joked with the â€˜Kid Correspondentâ€™ from the NFL Play 60 programme â€” one of three youngsters at the conference who were allowed to ask questions â€” who wanted to know how he keeps his body healthy for such demanding performances.

â€œEating smash burgers and thinking about the Super Bowl halftime show at 4 a.m.â€

He added heâ€™s been working out and eating healthy, though heâ€™s had to make sacrifices: â€œIâ€™m not even playing that much dominoes and thatâ€™s just killing me, bro.â€

Although this isnâ€™t his first rodeo, six years ago he joined Jennifer Lopez and Shakira on stage for Super Bowl LIV, yet he insists the return wasnâ€™t part of some master plan.

â€œMy biggest achievement, my biggest pleasure is just create, have fun doing it, and connect with the people,â€ he added.

What should fans expect Sunday? â€œAs I said, I just want people to have fun. Itâ€™s gonna be huge, the party is going to be what people always can expect from me. Of course, a lot of my culture, but I really donâ€™t want to give any spoilers.

â€œItâ€™s going to be fun and itâ€™s going to be a party,â€ he added.

â€”Reporting by Angelica Medina in Mexico City; Editing by David Gregorio
news.author: Kendrick Lamar

news.title: Kathy Hochulâ€™s Second-Term Prospects Look Brighter Than Ever
news.text: New York Democrat Governor Kathy Hochulâ€™s reelection prospects seem brighter than ever as she secures key endorsements and polling shows her with a comfortable lead in the primary and general election. Hochul's campaign spokesperson Ryan Radulovacki told Newsweek that New Yorkers are â€œseeing the results this governor is delivering for them, on public safety, bringing down costs, and standing up to [President Donald] Trump.â€ â€œItâ€™s always a good day to be on Team Hochul. Less so for Team Blakeman, who have to contend with their boss quadrupling down on his support for Trumpâ€™s ICE and their abuses of power, tariffs making everything expensive, and excusing every single thing Donald Trump does,â€ he said. Nassau County Executive Bruce Blakeman, running against Hochul as a Republican, told Newsweek on Friday that New Yorkers are not â€œwinning under Kathy Hochul with the highest taxes in the nation, soaring energy bills, and an affordability crisis that is pushing families and businesses out of New York every day.â€ He added: â€œIf thatâ€™s winning, thereâ€™s something seriously wrong with the scoreboard.â€ Newsweek also reached out to the campaign of Lieutenant Governor Antonio Delgado who is challenging her in the primary for comment via email. Why It Matters New York is a historically solidly Democratic state, but Republicans have made inroads with key voter groups such as Latino, Asian American and young voters. This yearâ€™s gubernatorial race will be a key test as to whether Democrats are able to win back those voters who shifted toward Republicans in recent years. Hochul became governor after then-Governor Andrew Cuomo resigned in 2021 over a report from Attorney General Letitia James' office alleging he sexually harassed multiple female employees and created a toxic work environment. She faced a closer-than-expected reelection in 2022, winning by just over six points against Republican Lee Zeldin. That marked the weakest Democratic performance in years. What To Know Despite Hochulâ€™s underperformance in 2022, and expectations that this year could again be competitive, the Democratic governor seems favored in recent polls to comfortably win reelection as the party has rallied behind her candidacy. Her polling position has improved since last year. The latest poll from Siena College showed Hochul with 54 percent of the vote compared to Blakemanâ€™s 28 percent support. In the primary, 64 percent of Democrats said they would back Hochul compared to just 11 percent of Democrats who planned to cast their ballot for Delgado. That poll surveyed 802 registered voters from January 26-28, with a margin of error of plus or minus 4.3 percentage points. A John Zogby Strategies poll earlier in January similarly showed the governor with a comfortable lead of 14 points (53 to 39 percent) over Blakeman and a 52-point lead over Delgado (64 to 12 percent). It surveyed 844 likely voters from January 6-8 and had a margin of error of plus or minus 3.4 percentage points. Most polls released in 2025 showed Hochul with a lead, but with less than 50 percent in the general election. One poll from the Manhattan Institute, a conservative-leaning group, showed GOP Representative Elise Stefanik lead Hochul by one point (43 to 42 percent). It surveyed 900 voters from October 22-26, 2025. Stefanik, viewed as a potentially formidable challenger, has since dropped out. Blakeman, who has been endorsed by President Donald Trump, is less known across the state, according to a Siena College poll from December. However, he does have a history of winning elections in competitive Nassau County. New York Governor Kathy Hochul speaks at the 40th annual Tribute to Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. in New York City on January 19. Boris Heersink, professor of political science at Fordham University, told Newsweek that Hochul â€œis a lot more confident in her role as governorâ€ and has been â€œproactive in claiming credit for popular policy achievements.â€ She is also benefiting from the fact that 2026 is likely to be a better year for Democrats, he said. Democrats believe this year may be a â€œblue wave,â€ compared to 2022, when Republicans had a better year, due to Trumpâ€™s diminishing approval ratings. â€œDemocrats are fired up, many independents are unhappy with Trump, and weâ€™ve been seeing Latino voters in races in New Jersey and Texas move back to the Democratic side at a very high rate. Given that New York was already still a majority Democratic state anyway, all this places her in a very comfortable position,â€ Heersink said. Harvey Schantz, a professor of political science at the State University of New York, Plattsburgh, told Newsweek Hochul has been able to get â€œthe progressive and moderate factions of the Democratic Party behind her.â€ â€œIn 2025-2026 Hochul has successfully punched away at Donald Trump in order to raise her own reelection chances. New York State registered voters gave Donald Trump only 34% approval in the latest Siena Poll, allowing Hochul to successfully use Trump as a foil. Building on Trumpâ€™s unpopularity, she has deftly tied prospective Republican challengers, including Bruce Blakeman, to Trump,â€ he said. Hochul and other New York Democrats will come into the election with â€œdecided advantages in party enrollment, the national political tide, and with a prospective Republican challenger who is not well known across the state,â€ Schantz said. Still, he noted there is a â€œlong way to go before Election Day.â€ Hochul Secures Key Endorsements Hochul secured the endorsement of New York City Mayor Zohran Mamdani in the Democratic gubernatorial primary. His endorsement could give Hochul, who is viewed as more of a mainstream Democrat, a boost among progressive voters in the state. â€œNew Yorkers deserve leaders who believe in transformation. Leaders who understand that hope is inspired by a vision, and sustained by change. Governor Kathy Hochul has earned my endorsement because she has chosen to govern in that spirit. And in this moment, that choice matters,â€ Mamdani wrote in an opinion article for The Nation. Mamdaniâ€™s endorsement may prevent â€œmajor intra-party conflict over the nomination,â€ Heersink said. â€œNobody else of name is challenging Hochul â€“ and having Mamdani on her side may prevent any of the more left-leaning parts of the party from trying (including by running as an independent). It also signals to Democratic voters in New York City â€“ who often feel neglected by Albany but whose votes are crucial to state-wide victories â€“ that Hochul is more open to helping the city than governors have been in the past,â€ he said. Meanwhile, The New York Times reported that she is poised to receive the endorsement from New Yorkâ€™s entire Congressional delegation over Delgado. Those endorsements would cross the ideological spectrum as well as the stateâ€™s regional divides. The publication noted that her future was â€œslightly precariousâ€ at the same point in 2022 as she faced primaries from Representative Tom Suozzi, a centrist, and Jumaane Williams, a progressive who serves as New York Cityâ€™s public advocate. She did, however, lose support over her lieutenant governor pick. Hochul Leads Betting Odds for New York Governor Race Hochul also leads betting odds in the New York gubernatorial race. Kalshi gave her a 92 percent chance of victory on Fridayâ€”up from 85 percent in January 2025. Polymarket similarly gave her a 91 percent chance of winning in November. The 2022 midterms represented a challenge for New York Democrats amid concerns about crime. Democrats in all statewide races faced diminished margins, but no race was as close as that of Hochul. Since then, she has increased her name recognition across the state and has seen her approval rating increase. The latest Siena poll found that 49 percent of New Yorkers view Hochul favorably, which it said was her â€œbest everâ€ favorability in their polling. New York has not elected a Republican governor since George Patakiâ€™s reelection in 2002. But there have been signs that Democratsâ€™ grip on the state has slipped. Former Vice President Kamala Harris received less than 56 percent of the vote in New York during the 2024 presidential election, the weakest performance for a Democrat in decades. Democrats will be working to win back voters who drifted toward Republicans and Trump in this year's elections. Delgado has mounted a progressive challenge to Hochul but has trailed her in the polls. Meanwhile, Mamdani endorsing Hochul over Delgado has drawn some criticism from progressives. â€œEven with good intentions, this endorsement is a bad deal: a one-off child care promise pulled from reserves, no plan to tax the rich, and donors put first. We should tax the ultra-wealthy and corporations and fund universal child care in the budget. Not with couch-cushion money,â€ India Walton, Delgadoâ€™s running mate, wrote to X. What People Are Saying Boris Heersink, professor of political science at Fordham University, also told Newsweek: â€œIt is always possible that we might end up being surprised, but it seems like this should be a very straightforward win for Hochul. The big question might be how big her margin of victory will end up being. But her approval ratings have improved greatly, many of the issues that hurt her in 2022 (the aftereffects of school closings) arenâ€™t as salient anymore, Latino voters are angry about Trumpâ€™s ICE policies and are returning to the Democratic Party, and Democrats in general are expecting a strong midterm turnout.â€œ Siena pollster Steven Greenberg wrote in the polling release: â€œAs we start the second month of this much watched mid-term election year, Hochul has a commanding lead among registered voters over both Delgado, among Democrats, and Blakeman, with all voters. While a 49-40% favorability rating is not generally seen as something to gloat about, for Hochul it is a net seven point gain from December, but more noteworthy is the fact that it is the first time in four and a half years as governor that Hochul has had 49% of voters view her favorably in a Siena poll.â€ New York state Senator Jabari Brisport, a socialist and Democrat, posted to X on Thursday he's still not supporting Hochul: â€œKathy Hochul is *by* billionaires, *for* billionaires. No politician will ever wield enough leverage to change that. Thankfully our movement is bigger than any one decision by any individual. Tax The Rich. Delgado 2026.â€ What Happens Next Forecasters give Hochul an advantage. The Cook Political Report classifies the race as being Safe Democratic, while Sabatoâ€™s Crystal Ball views it as Likely Democratic.
news.summary: Hochul, who faced a closer-than-expected race in 2022, is leading polls and securing key endorsements in her reelection bid.
news.author: Andrew Stanton

news.title: Trump Account Deletes AI Video Showing Obamas as Apes; White House, After Defending It, Claims Staff Member Had â€˜Erroneouslyâ€™ Posted Clip
news.text:
After a strong backlash over a racist video of the Obamas that was posted to President Donald Trumpâ€˜s account on Truth Social, the video has been deleted.

 A White House official told Variety that a staffer had erroneously made the post and that it has been taken down. The video, showing Michelle and Barack Obamaâ€˜s heads superimposed on the bodies of apes dancing in a jungle setting to â€œThe Lion Sleeps Tonight,â€ had been on Trumpâ€™s Truth Social page for nearly 12 hours.

 The videoâ€™s deletion came just a few hours after White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt had defended the Trump post as merely an â€œinternet meme.â€

 Leavitt had previously said, â€œThis is from an internet meme video depicting President Trump as the King of the Jungle and Democrats as characters from the Lion King. Please stop the fake outrage and report on something today that actually matters to the American public.â€

 The original video that the Obama animation came from, as cited by the White House, portrayed Trump as a lion. Barack and Michelle Obama were depicted as grinning, dancing apes. Other Democrats featured in the video included Joe Biden as a baboon, Kamala Harris as a tortoise, Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer as a zebra, House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries as a meerkat, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez as a donkey, New York City Mayor Zohran Mamdani as a hyena, and Hillary Clinton as a warthog.

 California Gov. Gavin Newsomâ€™s press office on X had called the video post with the Obamas as apes â€œdisgusting behavior by the Presidentâ€ and called on â€œevery single Republicanâ€ to â€œdenounce this.â€

 Sen. Tim Scott (R-South Carolina), who is the only Black GOP member of the Senate, wrote in a post on X Friday morning, â€œPraying it was fake because itâ€™s the most racist thing Iâ€™ve seen out of this White House. The President should remove it.â€
news.summary: After a strong backlash over a racist video of the Obamas that was posted to President Donald Trump’s account on Truth Social, the video has been deleted. A White House official told Variety that a staffer had erroneously made the post and that it has been taken down. The video, showing Michelle and Barack Obama’s […]
news.author: Todd Spangler

news.title: Analilia Mejia clings to narrow lead in New Jersey special election primary
news.text:
The Democratic primary for New Jerseyâ€™s 11th District remained close Friday, with fewer than 500 votes separating progressive organizer Analilia Mejia and former Rep. Tom Malinowski and an estimated 6,000 ballots still to be counted.

Still, Mejiaâ€™s late emergence into first place Thursday night set the stage for a potential upset for the activist who claimed the progressive lane in the crowded primary to fill Gov. Mikie Sherrillâ€™s former House seat. The latest results showed Mejia with 28.75 percent of the vote to Malinowskiâ€™s 27.96 percent, a difference of 486 votes, with 91 percent of the votes in, according to The Associated Press. 

Former Lt. Gov. Tahesha Way was in third place with 17.43 percent, followed by Essex County Commissioner Brendan Gill with 14.22 percent.

â€œI do think that we have emerged victorious, but I want to first make sure that every voterâ€™s voice is heard,â€ Mejia told reporters Friday. â€œIâ€™m already thinking about how do we consolidate so that we can tackle the bigger issue, which is how do we reclaim democracy in our nation and ensure that the voices of voters in New Jerseyâ€™s 11th Congressional District are actually heard.â€

Malinowski jumped to an early lead Thursday night after polls closed at 8 p.m. Eastern. But Mejia surged ahead around 10:15 p.m. as more returns came in. 

Some outlets had even called the race for Malinowski early Thursday night, leading Mejia to later share on social media the famous 1948 photo of President Harry Truman holding up a newspaper with the erroneous â€œDewey defeats Trumanâ€ headline. 

â€œThis race remains too close to call, with thousands of mail-in and provisional ballots still outstanding and yet to be counted,â€ Kaylie Haberstroh, Malinowskiâ€™s campaign manager, said in a statement. â€œGiven the volume of votes still to be reported and the way mail-in ballots have broken throughout this race, we remain confident heading into the continued count.â€

The winner will be favored in the April 16 special general election against Randolph Mayor Joe Hathaway, who was unopposed for the Republican nomination. Sherrill won a fourth term in 2024 by 15 points, while Kamala Harris carried the North Jersey district by 9 points the same year, according to calculations by Inside Elections with Nathan L. Gonzales. 

Progressives who supported Mejiaâ€™s campaign over the past several weeks have been celebrating her performance even as the race remains uncalled. Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders held a rally in the district last month for Mejia, who worked on his 2020 presidential bid, as well as a virtual rally for her on the eve of the election. She also had the backing of Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren, New York Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Massachusetts Rep. Ayanna S. Pressley, among other progressive members. 

â€œThis is the second big congressional primary in two weeks where voters chose the more progressive candidate and made clear they want Democrats who will shake up a broken political and economic system â€” not just be anti-Trump,â€ Adam Green, co-founder of the Progressive Change Campaign Committee, said in a statement, also referring to Texas Democrat Christian Menefeeâ€™s victory in a Jan. 31 special election runoff. 

Several progressive outside groups, including the Congressional Progressive Caucus PAC and Rep. Pramila Jayapalâ€™s leadership PAC, made late investments to boost Mejiaâ€™s campaign, which Jayapal said was enough to move the needle against bigger spenders.

â€œWhen thereâ€™s a real Organizer running, We donâ€™t need to match $ for $ â€” we just need to be in the ring,â€ the former Congressional Progressive Caucus chair said on social media. 

Mejia acknowledged that she entered the race with minimal name recognition, while Malinowski, who served two terms representing the neighboring 7th District, was more well-known from three past competitive races in the same media market. 

But Malinowski, who was the top fundraiser in the race, faced $2.3 million in opposition spending from the United Democracy Project, the super PAC of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee. While the group opposed Malinowski, who had reportedly said he was open to limits on funding for Israel, Mejia has been a sharper critic of the countryâ€™s government. 

â€œThe outcome in NJ-11 was an anticipated possibility, and our focus remains on who will serve the next full term in Congress,â€ the United Democracy Project said in a Friday statement. â€œUDP will be closely monitoring dozens of primary races, including the June NJ-11 primary, to help ensure pro-Israel candidates are elected to Congress.â€

Whoever wins the nomination, and ultimately the seat, will need to quickly pivot to the June primary to win the nomination for a full term. Still, the outcome so far raised questions about AIPACâ€™s influence in other Democratic primary contests this year, with the war in Gaza emerging as a differentiator among Democratic candidates in several races. 

Further tests could come next month in Illinois. Democrats running to succeed retiring Rep. Jan Schakowsky in the deep-blue 9th District include state Sen. Laura Fine and Evanston Mayor Daniel Biss, who are both Jewish. 

Biss has criticized Fine, including at a recent candidate forum, for receiving campaign contributions from donors who previously gave to Trump and AIPAC. Federal filings donâ€™t show that UDP has made any independent expenditures in that race, but the group has reportedly sent fundraising appeals on Fineâ€™s behalf. 

â€œLocal residents know that Laura Fineâ€™s campaign is being propped up by AIPAC and Republican megadonors, not grassroots support from the community sheâ€™s asking to represent,â€ Biss, who has Schakowskyâ€™s endorsement, said in a statement.
news.author: Posted February 6, 2026 At 5:05pm

news.title: Senate's lone Black Republican says Trump video "most racist thing I've seen out of this White House"
news.text:
Scott, who leads the Senate Republican campaign arm, posted Friday that he was "praying it was fake because it's the most racist thing I've seen out of this White House. The President should remove it."

"This is from an internet meme video depicting President Trump as the King of the Jungle and Democrats as characters from [T]he Lion King," White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said in a statement.

Black people being depicted as apes or monkeys is a centuries-old trope used for dehumanization and humiliation.

The post was ultimately taken down after being live for about 12 hours. 

Scott's post on X came after he reached out to the president privately but was unable to reach him, that source said.

"In cases like these, you don't want to ask and you don't want to know," the adviser said.

He's long been criticized for racist comments directed at individuals like the Obamas and former Vice President Kamala Harris â€” and groups of people like immigrants from Africa and Haiti.
news.summary:
Sen. Tim Scott asked President Trump to delete his social media post on Friday that portrayed the Obamas as apes, calling it "the most racist thing I've seen out of this White House."


The post was later taken down, per a White House official who said it was made in error by a staffer. Why it matters: Republicans rarely engage with the backlash to Trump posts. But Scott (R-S.C.), the only Black Republican in the Senate, responded quickly.


Scott, who leads the Senate Republican campaign arm, posted Friday that he was "praying it was fake because it's the most racist thing I've seen out of this White House. The President should remove it."Driving the news: Trump's Thursday post, made at 11:44pm ET, depicts former President Obama and former First Lady Michelle Obama as apes in an AI meme video portraying Trump as King of the Jungle.

news.title: Trump sparks outrage with video depicting Obamas as monkeys
news.text:
US President Donald Trump triggered outrage on Friday after he posted a video depicting Barack Obama, the first Black president in American history, and his wife Michelle as monkeys.

Top Democrats condemned the post as â€œracist,â€ even as the White House rejected what it called â€œfake outrageâ€ and said the video posted late Thursday on Trumpâ€™s Truth Social account was from an â€œinternet meme.â€

Near the end of the one-minute-long video promoting conspiracies about Republican Trumpâ€™s 2020 election loss, the Obamas are shown with their faces on the bodies of monkeys for about one second.

The song â€œThe Lion Sleeps Tonightâ€ plays in the background when the Obamas appear.

The video repeats false allegations that ballot-counting company Dominion Voting Systems helped steal the 2020 election from Trump and hand victory to Joe Biden, who was Obamaâ€™s vice president at the time.

â€œThis is from an internet meme video depicting President Trump as the King of the Jungle and Democrats as characters from the Lion King,â€ White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt said in a statement to AFP.

â€œPlease stop the fake outrage and report on something today that actually matters to the American public,â€ added Leavitt.

As of early Friday morning, the video had been liked several thousand times on the presidentâ€™s social media platform.

The office of California Governor Gavin Newsom, a potential 2028 Democratic presidential candidate and a prominent Trump critic, slammed the post.

â€œDisgusting behaviour by the President. Every single Republican must denounce this. Now,â€ Newsomâ€™s press office account posted on X.

Ben Rhodes, a former top national security advisor and close confidant to Barack Obama, also condemned the imagery.

â€œLet it haunt Trump and his racist followers that future Americans will embrace the Obamas as beloved figures while studying him as a stain on our history,â€ he wrote on X.

â€“ â€˜Birtherâ€™ conspiracy â€“ 

Obama is the only Black president in American history and backed Trumpâ€™s opponent Kamala Harris on the campaign trail in the 2024 presidential election.

Billionaire Trump launched his own political career by pushing the racist and false â€œbirtherâ€ conspiracy theory that his Democratic predecessor was lying about being born in the United States.

Trump has long had a bitter rivalry with Obama, who was president from 2009 to 2017, taking particular umbrage at the Democratâ€™s popularity and the fact that he won the Nobel Peace Prize.

In the first year of his second term in the White House, Trump has ramped up his use of hyper-realistic but fabricated AI visuals on Truth Social and other platforms, often glorifying himself while lampooning his critics.

He has used the provocative posts to rally his conservative base.

Last year, Trump posted a video generated by artificial intelligence showing Barack Obama being arrested in the Oval Office and appearing behind bars in an orange jumpsuit.

Later, he posted an AI clip of House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries â€” who is Black â€” wearing a fake mustache and a sombrero.

Jeffries called the image racist.

Since returning to the White House, Trump has drawn criticism from his opponents for leading a crusade against diversity, equity and inclusion (DEI) programs.

One of Trumpâ€™s first acts was to terminate all federal government DEI programs, including related policies in the military.

The drive to rid the armed forces of what Trump has derided as â€œwokeâ€ initiatives has also seen the removal from some military academy bookshelves of scores of books that cover the US history of racial discrimination.

US federal anti-discrimination programs were born of the 1960s civil rights struggle, mainly led by Black Americans, for equality and justice after hundreds of years of slavery, whose abolition in 1865 saw other institutional forms of racism enforced.
news.summary:
Donald Trump sparks outrage by posting a video depicting Barack and Michelle Obama as monkeys, prompting top Democrats to condemn the post as racist.

news.title: Why the Wailing and Gnashing of Teeth Over the Decline of the Washington Post?
news.text:
"It's good to be shifty in a new country," was 19th-century advice given to immigrants. It was needed. Europeans had never even imagined a society so mobile, so dynamic as America.

The period between 1875 and 1900, often called the Gilded Age, saw the most rapid economic growth in American history. The U.S. transitioned from an agrarian society to the world's leading industrial power, driven by a "mobile and dynamic" spirit often noted by observers of the time.

This period was also the peak of westward expansion. The completion of the first Transcontinental Railroad in 1869 shifted migration from slow wagon trains to rapid rail travel. By 1870, approximately 400,000 settlers had made the trek west along major trails like the Oregon Trail.

The Homestead Act (1862) fueled a massive wave of farming settlement by providing 160 acres of free land to anyone willing to improve it. Between 1862 and 1900, the government transferred over 270 million acres to private citizens.

Economic dynamism and unprecedented mobility led to the most revolutionary cultural changes in history. Those changes included the decline and eventual destruction of several industries in America. Blacksmiths, wheelwrights, and other small-business and artisanal workers associated with the "horse and buggy" pre-industrial economy were not just "workers"; they were critical members and pillars of their communities. Their shops were often the physical and social center of a village.

Even more importantly, the decline of these trades meant the collapse of the formal apprentice system, which for centuries had provided young people with a clear path to social mobility and financial freedom.

There was a social cost to these changes. Labor unrest, unemployment, and a sense of being unmoored from society all contributed to a pervasive fear and trepidation.

But those who were "shifty" and adaptable to the new realities thrived in this new America. One man's loss was another man's opportunity. Those who didn't recognize these opportunities floundered.

Such is capitalism. 

Perhaps that's why the left is melting down over the Washington Post's decline and eventual shuttering. Leftists don't understand capitalism. They don't recognize opportunity. And they're "shifty" in all the wrong ways.

This week, the Washington Post laid off about a third of its staff. They lost $100 million over the last year, which, even for a very wealthy man like Jeff Bezos, is a lot of money.

The executive editor of the Post, Matt Murray, gave the 100% correct reason for why the Post was forced to take the actions it did: the layoffs were part of a restructuring effort and a shift away from a model that is â€œtoo rooted in a different era.â€

In what universe would it be unacceptable to make those cuts after losing $100 million? A left-wing universe, of course.

The liberal former editor of the paper, Marty Baron, said in a statement that the layoffs rank â€œamong the darkest days in the history of one of the worldâ€™s greatest news organizations.â€He criticized Mr. Bezosâ€™ decision to kill the paperâ€™s planned endorsement of Vice President Harris in the 2024 election, as well as the billionaireâ€™s order that the editorial page publish columns dedicated to â€œpersonal liberties and free markets.â€Those decisions, according to Mr. Baron, made the paperâ€™s financial struggles â€œinfinitely worseâ€ as they led to â€œhundreds of thousandsâ€ of readers being â€œdriven away.â€

Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez suggested that the move by the Post was a conspiracy of some sort.

When Jeff Bezos bought WaPo, he immediately took control of the opinions section. Now, he's laying off hundreds of journalists, including those covering Amazon.This isnâ€™t a coincidence. Itâ€™s the result of billionaires with vested political agendas taking over our media.â€” Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (@RepAOC) February 4, 2026

As opposed to leftists with a vested political agenda running the paper? Bezos is a businessman who read the tea leaves and saw moderating the Post's liberalism as a good, bottom-line move. He was probably wrong because he couldn't have imagined the outcry that resulted after his refusal to endorse Kamala Harris in 2024. The explosion of hysterical opposition from the left, no doubt, gave subscribers a false impression of what exactly Bezos was trying to do. 

In effect, the liberals' over-the-top reaction to Bezos's moves in 2024 became a self-fulfilling prophecy.

Democratic Socialist Senator Bernie Sanders said, â€œIf Jeff Bezos could afford to spend $75 million on the Melania movie & $500 million for a yacht to sail off to his $55 million wedding to give his wife a $5 million ring, please donâ€™t tell me he needed to fire one-third of the Washington Post staff. Democracy dies in oligarchy.â€â€œJeff Bezos just fired hundreds of reporters at the Washington Post â€” including the Amazon reporter holding his OWN company accountable. Reminder: Jeff Bezosâ€™ net worth is nearly $250,000,000,000,â€ wrote far-left Democratic Senator Elizabeth Warren. A weekend host at the left-wing network MS NOW, Jonathan Capehart, said that with the layoffs, the Post is â€œcomplicitâ€ in â€œkillingâ€ democracy.

This is the hubris of the journalism business. The death of newspapers will not usher in an age of dictatorship. Only 7% of U.S. adults say they "often" get their news from printed newspapers or magazines. Nearly 70% of U.S. adults prefer reading their news online rather than in print. That's not close to any definition of "democratic" I'm aware of.

Since newspapers have yet to figure out a new online business model that can make money, they're stuck trying to make a go of it with a model that's been around for a thousand years.

It's not working. Newspapers will never be what they were 40 years ago. To "journalists" and other purveyors of what they consider to be "truth": Stop whining about the inevitability of change. Bari Weiss stopped whining about anything and is now a multi-millionaire. 

It's good to be shifty in a new country.

The new year promises to be one of the most pivotal in recent history. Midterm elections will determine if we continue to move forward or slide back into lawfare, impeachments, and the toleration of fraud.

PJ Media will give you all the information you need to understand the decisions that will be made this year. Insightful commentary and straight-on, no-BS news reporting have been our hallmarks since 2005.

news.author: Rick Moran
